*G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28*.proposition: NOW COMES the Plaintiff, **Maria Torres**, and respectfully files this *Complaint for Modification* pursuant to *G.L. c. 208, § 28*, *G.L. c. 209C, § 20*, and the equitable powers of this Honorable Court.

*G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20*.proposition: NOW COMES the Plaintiff, **Maria Torres**, and respectfully files this *Complaint for Modification* pursuant to *G.L. c. 208, § 28*, *G.L. c. 209C, § 20*, and the equitable powers of this Honorable Court.

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: Under *G.L. c. 208, § 28* and pertinent case law, a custody or parenting plan may be modified upon a showing of a **material and substantial change in circumstances** since entry of the prior judgment, and where modification is **in the best interests of the child**.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The decision in Yannas is a removal/custody case decided in the context of an initial divorce judgment, not on a complaint for modification of an existing custody or parenting plan. The court interprets G.L. c. 208, § 30 and discusses the ‘best interests of the child’ and the ‘real advantage’ standard for removal, but it does not set out or apply the ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ requirement for modification under G.L. c. 208, § 28. Therefore it does not provide authority for the specific modification standard stated in the proposition.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents who is a native of . . . this commonwealth . . . shall not, if of suitable age to signify his consent, be removed out of this commonwealth without such consent, or, if under that age, without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815)…”}

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Under *G.L. c. 208, § 28* and pertinent case law, a custody or parenting plan may be modified upon a showing of a **material and substantial change in circumstances** since entry of the prior judgment, and where modification is **in the best interests of the child**.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal/relocation case decided under G.L. c. 208, § 30, not a § 28 modification-standard case. While the court discusses modification procedurally (the father filed a complaint for modification), the decision does not set out or apply the “material and substantial change in circumstances” plus “best interests of the child” standard that governs custody/parenting plan modifications under § 28. Its substantive analysis is framed solely in terms of whether removal is in the children’s best interests under § 30, so it does not provide authority for the specific § 28 modification proposition stated.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that “[a] minor child of divorced parents who is a native of or has resided five years within this [C]ommonwealth and over whose custody and maintenance a probate court has jurisdiction shall not ... be removed out of this [C]ommonwealth ... if under [the] age [of consent], without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.” “The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.” Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985).

*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.proposition: The best interests of the child are paramount in all custody determinations.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that in custody decisions the court’s overriding concern must be the promotion of the child’s best interests and welfare, and cites earlier Massachusetts authority framing the child’s welfare as the controlling consideration. The custody analysis throughout the opinion is explicitly governed by this “best interests” standard, confirming that the child’s best interests are paramount in custody determinations.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.relevant_excerpt: “However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare. … [T]he Supreme Judicial Court in Jenkins v. Jenkins… added: ‘In providing for the custody of a minor child, while the feelings and wishes of the parents should not be disregarded, the happiness and the welfare of the children should be the controlling consideration.’”

*Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406 (1976.proposition: The best interests of the child are paramount in all custody determinations.
*Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406 (1976.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that in custody matters “the governing principle” and “dominating rule” is the welfare of the child, and that the child’s happiness and welfare are the “controlling consideration.” The court applies that standard to affirm the custody award. This directly aligns with the proposition that the child’s best interests are paramount in custody determinations.
*Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406 (1976.relevant_excerpt: “In Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545, 555 (1930), we stated the basic rule applicable in such cases as follows: ‘The governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child. That is so both as matter of law and as matter of humanity. Every public and private consideration establishes this as the dominating rule.’ … ‘In providing for the custody of a minor child, while the feelings and the wishes of the parents should not be disregarded, the happiness and the welfare of the child should be the controlling consideration.’”

*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..proposition: A court must evaluate the totality of circumstances, including the child’s emotional well-being, educational stability, and the feasibility of the parenting schedule.
*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The opinion expressly requires consideration of “all relevant factors” bearing on the child’s best interests in both custody/visitation and removal analyses. In discussing removal, the court cites Murray and Dickenson and lists factors including the impact of moving or not moving on the child’s emotional, physical, and developmental needs, and the possibility of alternative visitation schedules—i.e., the feasibility of the parenting schedule and the child’s stability. The court also stresses stability as “of enormous benefit to a child,” reflecting attention to emotional and educational continuity as part of the totality-of-circumstances inquiry.
*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: “In cases such as this, our duty as a reviewing court is to ensure that the record reflects that all relevant factors have been considered by the judge, and that the decision is based on a fair weighing of the factors. … [A]t the second stage of the analysis, ‘[t]he relevant factors are: [1] whether the quality of the children’s lives will be improved, including any improvement that ‘may flow from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life’; [2] any possible ‘adverse effect of the elimination or curtailment of the children]’s association with the noncustodial parent’; [3] ‘the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the [children’s] emotional, physical, or developmental needs’; [4] the interests of both parents; and [5] the possibility of an alternative visitation schedule for the noncustodial parent.’ … In determining the best interests of the child, weight, of course, should be given to the fact that ‘[stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child….’”}

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: A court must evaluate the totality of circumstances, including the child’s emotional well-being, educational stability, and the feasibility of the parenting schedule.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The court repeatedly frames the governing test as the “best interests of the child” and emphasizes that the judge must weigh “all relevant factors,” including stability and continuity, work schedules, day care arrangements, and the ability of each parent to attend to the child’s medical and educational needs. While it does not list “emotional well‑being, educational stability, and feasibility of the parenting schedule” in a single formulaic sentence, the opinion clearly endorses a totality‑of‑circumstances analysis that encompasses those elements. Thus it provides general support for the proposition, though not in those exact words.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “The determination of which parent will promote a child’s best interests rests within the discretion of the judge… However, we will not sustain an award of custody ‘unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed.’ … [T]he judge’s findings reflect that he considered all of the circumstances before him and attempted to structure a permanent custodial award to serve the best interests of Kali, including her continued and substantial involvement with both parents.”

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: When a parent relocates to a significantly different geographic area that impacts the child’s routine and schooling, such relocation constitutes a **material change** justifying modification.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly rejects the idea that the custodial parent’s relocation itself constitutes the material and substantial change needed to justify a modification of custody. The court holds that a request for removal is distinct from a request to modify custody, and that modification must rest on a material change in circumstances “other than the move.” Thus, the case stands for the opposite of the claimed proposition.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Our decision today, that a request for modification of custody is distinct from a request to relocate and must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the move, is consistent with these decisions and with G. L. c. 208, § 28 …”

*Williams v. Massa*, 431 Mass. 619 (2000.proposition: The Court may adjust parental access to balance the child’s need for stability with continued meaningful contact with both parents.
*Williams v. Massa*, 431 Mass. 619 (2000.support_reasoning: The case directly involves custody and parental access and shows the court balancing the children’s need for emotional stability and appropriate decision-making (given their special needs) with preserving the mother’s “significant” continuing role in their lives. The SJC approves a structure of joint legal custody, shared physical custody of the son, sole physical custody of the daughter with mandated therapeutic contact with the father, and modifies only the procedural mechanism for future custody changes. This reflects an approach of tailoring parental access to both stability and ongoing meaningful contact with both parents, though the discussion is brief and framed mainly as a procedural correction.
*Williams v. Massa*, 431 Mass. 619 (2000.relevant_excerpt: “The wife has limited insight into the children’s special needs, and was not, at the time of trial, a positive force in the children’s lives. … On the other hand, the judge found that both children were deeply allied with their mother, and that she must continue in a significant way in their lives, ‘despite the worrisome behaviors she exhibits in her parenting.’ … The judge… declared that the parties will have joint legal custody of the two children, shared physical custody of the son, and that the wife will have sole physical custody of the daughter… [and] ordered weekly therapy sessions between the husband and the daughter.”}

*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: The Court may adjust parental access to balance the child’s need for stability with continued meaningful contact with both parents.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The court explicitly upholds a custody order that balances the child’s need for stability with maintaining a meaningful relationship with both parents. The opinion affirms that, although stability and protection from alienating conduct required primary physical custody with Hunter, the judge appropriately structured substantial parenting time, web‑camera contact, and phone calls to preserve Jill’s relationship with Rose, and even contemplated adjusting the plan if Rose moved back. This directly supports the proposition that the Court may adjust parental access to reconcile stability with ongoing contact with both parents.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “The judge found that disrupting the attachment a child has to a parent and behaving in ways designed to alienate a child from that parent causes harm that can be long term, and if sole physical custody must be awarded because of geographic distance between parents, ‘it is in the best interests of a child to be in the sole custody of the parent who can support the involvement of both parents rather than with the parent who alienates the child from the other parent.’ … The judge’s custody order gave Rose frequent contact with Jill, including parenting time one weekend per month in Massachusetts, five weeks in the summer, school vacations, holidays, Web camera sessions three evenings per week, and telephone calls once per week… Moreover, the judge stated that, should Rose decide to move back to Massachusetts, the parties must work in good faith to adjust their parenting plan to meet Jill’s best interests.”

*M.C. v. T.K.*, 463 Mass. 226 (2012).proposition: Courts have recognized that schedules resulting in excessive travel, late nights, or interference with school and extracurricular activities may not serve the child’s best interests.
*M.C. v. T.K.*, 463 Mass. 226 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns child support in a shared physical custody context with high-income parents and does not discuss parenting schedules that involve excessive travel, late nights, or interference with school or extracurricular activities. Its references to extracurricular activities and private school are solely about allocation of costs and best interests in terms of affordability, not about rejecting particular time-sharing or travel schedules. Therefore it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about problematic schedules and children’s best interests.
*M.C. v. T.K.*, 463 Mass. 226 (2012).relevant_excerpt: "[I]f a judge determines that there are ‘child-related expenses such as extracurricular activities [or] private school . . . which are in the best interest of the child and which are affordable by the parties, the [judge] may allocate costs to the parties on a case-by-case basis’... In addition, the judge should determine whether current extracurricular activities and private school are affordable and in the best interests of the child, and allocate responsibility for such costs in accordance with considerations set forth in the guidelines and the child support principles outlined in this opinion."

*Malachi M. v. Quincy M.*, 484 Mass. 247.proposition: Courts have recognized that schedules resulting in excessive travel, late nights, or interference with school and extracurricular activities may not serve the child’s best interests.
